coredata.dc:title: Ecological analyses of street trees of Indian cities to achieve United Nations sustainable development goals
coredata.prism:copyright: © 2024 Ecological Society of China. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
coredata.prism:publisher: Ecological Society of China. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:creator: Ekka, Pawan
Shilky,
Baishya, Ratul
Saikia, Purabi
coredata.dc:description: The present study determined the community characteristics, structural composition, and regeneration status of street trees in two major Indian cities viz., Ranchi and Delhi. A total of 96 species of 86 genera belonging to 34 families were documented in the urban streets of Ranchi (of which 59 spp. were in the IUCN Red-list), while 64 species of 56 genera belonging to 28 families (of which 47 spp. were in the IUCN Red-list) were reported in Delhi. The study reported a very high species diversity index (H′) in both Ranchi (3.98) and Delhi (3.47), with similar species evenness (0.85). Fabaceae and Ficus were the predominant family and genus, respectively in both cities. The similarity of street trees of Ranchi and Delhi is quite low in terms of all the β-diversity indices (SI = 38.75% and dissimilarity = 61.25%; Cj = 0.24 and dissimilarity = 0.76; BCij = 0.61 and similarity = 0.39). The total street tree density in Ranchi (217 ind. ha−1) and Delhi (637 ind. ha−1) varied significantly, while the dominance (basal area) of both cities were quite similar (20.67 m2ha−1 and 21.70 m2ha−1) due to the predominance of young and adult individuals (GBH ≥30–90 cm) in the street tree community at Ranchi and pole and young individuals (GBH ≥ 10–60) in Delhi. The regeneration potential of street trees in both cities was quite concerning because the majority of street trees at Ranchi (62.5% of 96 spp.) and Delhi (57.38% of 64 spp.) had shown no regeneration. It is advised that re-greening, planting a variety of native tree tracts in urban niches, and tree planting in a ratio of one to three be implemented to counteract artificial urban land, maintain urban biodiversity and achieve UN SDGs.

Alpha (α) and beta (β) diversity
Population structure
Regeneration status

head.ce:title: Ecological analyses of street trees of Indian cities to achieve United Nations sustainable development goals

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Environmental Sciences, Central University of Jharkhand, Ranchi 835222, India
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Department of Environmental Sciences, Central University of Jharkhand, Ranchi-835222, India; ORCID IDs: 0000-0002-6113-9626 (PE), 0000-0001-8292-0385 (S), 0000-0001-5481-282X (PS)

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Botany, University of Delhi, Delhi 110007, India
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Department of Botany, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India; ORCID ID: 0000-0002-4149-6466 (RB)

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The present study determined the community characteristics, structural composition, and regeneration status of street trees in two major Indian cities viz., Ranchi and Delhi. A total of 96 species of 86 genera belonging to 34 families were documented in the urban streets of Ranchi (of which 59 spp. were in the IUCN Red-list), while 64 species of 56 genera belonging to 28 families (of which 47 spp. were in the IUCN Red-list) were reported in Delhi. The study reported a very high species diversity index (H′) in both Ranchi (3.98) and Delhi (3.47), with similar species evenness (0.85). Fabaceae and Ficus were the predominant family and genus, respectively in both cities. The similarity of street trees of Ranchi and Delhi is quite low in terms of all the β-diversity indices (SI = 38.75% and dissimilarity = 61.25%; Cj = 0.24 and dissimilarity = 0.76; BCij = 0.61 and similarity = 0.39). The total street tree density in Ranchi (217 ind. ha−1) and Delhi (637 ind. ha−1) varied significantly, while the dominance (basal area) of both cities were quite similar (20.67 m2ha−1 and 21.70 m2ha−1) due to the predominance of young and adult individuals (GBH ≥30–90 cm) in the street tree community at Ranchi and pole and young individuals (GBH ≥ 10–60) in Delhi. The regeneration potential of street trees in both cities was quite concerning because the majority of street trees at Ranchi (62.5% of 96 spp.) and Delhi (57.38% of 64 spp.) had shown no regeneration. It is advised that re-greening, planting a variety of native tree tracts in urban niches, and tree planting in a ratio of one to three be implemented to counteract artificial urban land, maintain urban biodiversity and achieve UN SDGs.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: All data generated or analyzed during this study are included in this article. Rest, raw data may be available with proper request to the corresponding author.

ce:section.ce:para: >50% of the world's population now lives in cities [1] and it is anticipated to increase to 68% by 2050 [2] as a result of the rapid urbanization that is occurring, especially in developing countries like India [3]. Overexploitation of natural resources has created a big gap between the demand and supply of natural resources [4]. Poverty, population pressure, infrastructural development, and agricultural expansion as well as intensification are the major threats to natural resources [5,6,7,8] which causes an increase in the movement rate of rural population towards urban areas. Urbanization has several advantages for Asian countries [9], in particular, India and other South Asian countries can change their economies by better utilizing the opportunities provided by urbanization [10]. On the contrary, urban development harms urban ecosystems and surrounding environmental conditions including the urban heat island (UHI) effects, air pollution, and changes to hydrological systems [11]. To cope with this situation, plantations of fast-growing tree species and other plant species are being established in the global scale to meet the increasing demand for ecological goods and services, believing that a large amount of biomass can be harvested within short span and can improve the overall environmental conditions [12,13]. In addition to these, the presence of roadside trees and urban greenery, can promote psychological and physiological regrowth by improving mental health, lowering blood pressure and anxiety, reducing death rates, and lowering physical inactivity while encouraging active lifestyles with greater cardiovascular benefits [14]. Street tree diversity and composition in urban landscapes are becoming increasingly important for scientific research [15], urban design and enforcement [16], climate change adaptation and mitigation [17], as well as for overall sustainability of urban areas [18]. There are many different kinds of trees in urban environments, both native and non-native [19], with notable levels of species richness in the streets [20]. Street trees serve as key natural elements of urban ecosystems offering a range of ecological and social benefits, such as carbon retention and sequestration, maintaining biodiversity [21], better air quality, stormwater runoff management, noise suppression, and UV-B radiation abatement [22]. Green spaces in urbanised areas can improve clean air and water, maintain energy flow, reduce the UHI effect, and offer recreational possibilities and economic benefits to city people [23]. These benefits can improve both the mental and physical well-being of city dwellers [24].

Integrated analysis of plant species composition and diversity offers a chance to quantify the impact of disruption on vegetation, habitat patterns, and the propagation of invasive species [25]. In urban areas, species richness is quite high due to a combination consisting of a high prevalence of exotic species, socioeconomic factors, heterogeneity in land use and land cover, and variations in soil and climatic parameters [26]. Tree species are pillars of urban ecosystems help to maintain plant species composition, mitigate environmental changes, and benefit a wide range of services to mankind [27]. Extreme industrialization can hinder alpha diversity due to unsuitable environmental conditions, whereas introducing new species with minimal to average levels of urbanization can boost alpha diversity [25]. Contrarily, beta diversity in urban vegetation often declines as a result of native species becoming extinct due to rivalry with invasive species or because native species cannot withstand the stresses that are often inherited in urban areas [25].

Exotic invaders, environmental damage, road salts [28], and restricted spacing [29] are significant streetscape components that can jeopardize the wholesome development and vitality of urban street trees [30]. A greater diversity of species corresponds with improved psychological and aesthetic advantages, and can also lessen the havoc caused by blizzards, drought, health issues, and other stresses [31]. Globally, studies regarding urban green spaces (UGSs) focus mainly on recreation, physical and mental health, and modulating services [32]. Scholars have continued to recommend integration of UGSs in urban planning and development [33]. In context to India, urban planning and forestry initiatives still lack in small cities due to absence of multidisciplinary evaluation and government policies, hindering compatible sustainable development [34,35]. The accomplishment of sustainable management initiatives including United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (specifically SDGs 11, 13, 15, and 16), requires the implementation of comprehensive plans for enhancing the density of UGSs, and the improvement of existing ones, relying on governmental actions, approaches, and regulations on UGSs [36,10]. Under the National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC), the Government of India introduced the National Mission of Green India and the National Mission on Sustainable Habitat to increase the carbon sink capacity of metropolitan areas by establishing afforestation schemes [37]. The National Urban and Community Forestry Advisory Council (NUCFAC) associates growing diversity with higher resilience in urban and community tree populations and promotes the introduction of site-appropriate species tolerant to insect and disease pests and climate change [38]. Urban planning and management must undergo a considerable transformation to achieve UN SDGs [39]. City's sustainability can be achieved through integration of all the three basic pillars of sustainability, viz., environmental, socio-economic, and cultural aspects as well as integrating pollution tolerant, highly productive, fast-growing trees in the urban streets [40]. Therefore, the present study focused on determining the street tree diversity of two randomly selected Indian cities and their associated ecological parameters to suggest most adaptable street trees according to the prevailing environmental conditions of the cities. It also highlights the importance of street tree communities for the development of urban greenery to achieve UN SDGs. It also addresses the knowledge gaps in distribution and species composition of street trees, management approaches, environmental conditions, and anthropogenic pressure.

The study was carried on and led in two randomly selected Indian cities viz., Ranchi and Delhi to determine the street tree diversity and related ecological characteristics. Ranchi is the capital city of the Indian state of Jharkhand, while Delhi is one of the metro cities located in the national capital (Fig. 1 ). Delhi is located on the banks of the Yamuna River, with latitudes of 28.24 to 28.53° N and longitudes of 76.50 to 77.20° E covering a total area of 1483 sq. km. Delhi is a small strip of northwest Indo-Gangetic plains surrounded by the Thar Desert, the Aravali Mountain, and the Himalayas [41]. Monsoon season in Delhi begins in the last week of June or the first week of July with a cumulative annual rainfall of 790 mm. Delhi has a mean annual maximum temperature of 46 °C and a minimal temperature of 4 °C, with December the coldest and June the hottest month. Delhi's vegetation is thorny scrub, which grows in arid and semi-arid areas classified as a ‘Tropical Thorn Forest’ and more specifically as a ‘Semi-Arid Open Scrub’ [42]. Conversely, Ranchi is the capital of the Indian state Jharkhand, located at 23.13° to 23.21° N latitude, 85.51° to 85.54° E longitude with a spatial extent of 5097 sq. km [43]. It resides on the eastern border of the Deccan Plateau, becoming the southernmost region of the Chhotanagpur Plateau and lies at an elevation ranging from 400 to 700 above mean sea level [44]. The combination of hilly terrain and dense tropical trees (primary and secondary tropical moist deciduous and dry deciduous forests) create a warm and modest climate throughout the year with an average of 1430 mm annual rainfall [45].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Alpha (α) and Beta (β) diversity of street trees
ce:section.ce:para:
Alpha (α) diversity of the street trees of the studied cities were determined using various ecological indices as summarized in Table 1.3. The present study reported a very high species diversity index (H′) in both Ranchi (3.98) and Delhi (3.47) which lies in the range (0.83 to 4.10) reported for various tropical forests of the Indian subcontinent [93]; [94] but comparatively higher than the other Indian cities including Bilaspur (3.32) [69], Puducherry (2.96) [71], Chennai (2.79) [79], Kamla Nehru Ridge, New Delhi (2.58) [95], and Asola Bhatti Wildlife Sanctuary, New Delhi (2.10) [95,96] (Table 2). On the other hand, the species dominance index (CD) was quite low for both the cities 0.03 (Ranchi) and 0.05 (Delhi) and within the reported range (0.021 to 0.092) of Indian forests [97,98]. Similarly, Dmg, Dmn, Pielou's evenness, and ENS were higher in Delhi (14.2, 2.37, 0.85, and 54, respectively) compared to Ranchi (8.6, 1.83, 0.84, and 32, respectively) (Table 4
). There have been reported variations in various diversity and dominance indices in the street trees in both Indian and global cities due to the development history of cities, cultural variables, urban forestry needs, and local governance [99]. Ranchi is a newly developing city (after being declared as the capital city of Jharkhand on 15 November 2000), beyond its main urban centers majority of its land area is surrounded by agricultural land and adjacent villages. The streets and roads passing these semi-developed urban regions have reported high species diversity due to the presence of natural forests in peri-urban areas beyond the municipal boundary that allows easy exchange of species in the urban regions. Moreover, the practice of mimicking and adapting suitable species in residential and agricultural plots in and around the main city for miscellaneous uses by residents and farmers contributes to increased species diversity of the street tree community. New Delhi's Avenue plantation was designed by Lutyens and Herbert Baker; it resembles a garden, providing a soothing greenery to counter Delhi's semi-arid environment [100]. Town planners, foresters, and horticulturists selected thirteen evergreen and drought-resistant trees for avenue planting [101] including eight common Indian trees, such as S. cumini, Azadirachta indica A.Juss., Terminalia arjuna (Roxb. ex DC.) Wight & Arn., Ficus religiosa L., and Tamarindus indica L. and one imported species, the African sausage tree, Kigelia africana (Lam.) Benth. [102]. The natural forests of Delhi are highly protected and due to positive management practices of authorities in the last two decades, the green cover of Delhi has increased significantly from 151 sq. km in 2001 to 342 sq. km in 2021, which indicates the improvement in the forest cover from 10.2% in 2001 to 23.06% in 2021 of the total geographical area of Delhi [103].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Population structure and regeneration status of street trees
ce:section.ce:para: The present study recorded the maximum number of species at the adult stage (GBH: ≥10 cm) in both Ranchi (96 spp.) and Delhi (64 spp.) followed by saplings (41 spp. in Ranchi and 22 spp. in Delhi), and seedlings (18 spp. in Ranchi and 12 spp. in Delhi). The GBH of trees in Ranchi ranged from 10 to 1007 cm with a mean GBH of 88.17 cm ± 1.60 (SE), while in Delhi it ranged from 10 to 323 cm with a mean GBH of 54.40 cm ± 1.13 (SE). In the streets of Ranchi, F. benghalensis had the highest GBH (1007 cm), while T. arjuna (323 cm) in Delhi. The highest percentage of individuals in Ranchi (29%) were contributed by young trees (GBH: >30–60 cm), followed by adult (GBH: >60–90 cm) (24%), old (GBH: ˃120 cm) (21%), mature (GBH: >90–120 cm) (14%), and pole (GBH: ≥10–30 cm) (13%), whereas in Delhi dominant individuals were poles (GBH: ≥10–30 cm) (32.7%) followed by young (GBH: >30–60 cm) (31.3%), adult (GBH: >60–90 cm) (21.6%), mature (GBH: >90–120 cm) (9.2%), and old (GBH: ˃120 cm) (5.2%). The population structure of street trees in both the studied cities varies due to different geographic and climatic conditions, species selection, age of trees, and management approaches [74]. The predominance of adult trees in Ranchi and poles in Delhi indicates that the street tree community in both the studied cities have a high potential for carbon sequestration for a longer duration [104]. Proper management of these street trees can be an economical and ecosystem-based approach to mitigate micro-climatic changes in an urban landscape [105].

The present study exhibited varied diversity and richness of tree species in two different cities (urban habitats) ranging from 64 to 96 spp. due to geography, anthropogenic disturbances, habitat modification, management strategies, and policy implications. The study also showed that the frequency of occurrences and predominance of very rare species decreased with increasing species richness. The majority of the species at Ranchi (62.50%) and Delhi (57.38%) have shown no regeneration, which is a matter of concern as it indicates that species may disappear soon. The ground vegetation is usually cleared from time to time by the city management to encourage the growth of a specific group of plants, especially the ornamental species may be one of the major causes of the no regeneration of the majority of tree species in both cities. It is recommended that planting a ratio of trees, re-greening, and creating diverse tracts of native trees in urban niches should be adopted to counter artificial urban land. The difference in tree dynamics gives insight into the future prediction of critical ecosystem services, environmental constraints, climate challenges, sustainability, and social investment in public health care. Development of new policies through research and evaluation of environmental conditions, local socio-political history, the bioregional context of urban forestry practices, and future goals is necessary for a sustainable urban landscape with street trees. The study of urban tree dynamics is crucial for the conservation and management of urban biodiversity, sustainability, and various ecosystem services in terms of clean air, aesthetics, and climate control. The present study will enlighten the state of urban tree communities in Indian cities and serve as baseline information to carry out research, innovations, sustainable development, planning, and policy for the conservation and management of urban biodiversity to counter the effects of urbanization, environmental degradation, and climate change. It is suggested that residential areas, commercial complexes, and government premises should own at least 10% of the total land area for development of green spaces with special emphasis on native plant species.

ce:section.ce:para: The Ministry of Tribal Affairs, Government of India through an NFST fellowship (Award no. 202122-NFST-JHA-00639 dated 14 October 2022) to Pawan Ekka.

PE & S: participated in the field data collection, analyses, and interpretation, and drafted the manuscript; PS: conceived the study, assisted in species identification, and also contributed to finalizing the manuscript; RB: contributed to finalizing the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This study was supported by funding from the Ministry of Tribal Affairs, Government of India to Pawan Ekka through an NFST fellowship (Award no. 202122-NFST-JHA-00639 dated 14 October 2022) for a Ph.D. We also thankfully acknowledge the financial assistance and infrastructure facilities provided under the DST-FIST Program, Govt. of India (Ref. No. SR/FST/ES-I/2019/55 (C) dated 25 March 2021) to the Department of Environmental Sciences, Central University of Jharkhand (CUJ), Ranchi. We are also thankful to the CUJ for providing institutional fellowship to Shilky to carry out her Ph.D. research. The help and support received from the Jharkhand State Forest Department, Ranchi, Delhi Development Authority, New Delhi, and people involved in the survey and sampling are duly acknowledged.
